subject: Re: A case for adding logging of assertions to junit
msgSnippet: ... Jester (http://jester.sourceforge.net) is pretty useful for getting a handle on how good a set of unknown tests are and where problems lie. However, the
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Mark Levison" <mlevison@...> wrote:
> If I'm invited to come and help with a project which is struggling
> with their tests (not having done TDD from the start), I can see using
> the log files as a way of helping me better understand what's going
> on. Are there tests without assertions? Are there tests with many
> assertions? etc.

Jester (http://jester.sourceforge.net) is pretty useful for getting a
handle on how good a set of unknown tests are and where problems lie.
However, the analysis run taking a long time. Ivan has written a
simple version that is very easy to run. More info here:
http://ivan.truemesh.com/archives/000725.html.

There's a similar tool called Jumble that is much faster because it
fiddles with bytecodes instead of rerunning the entire build after
every mutation. However, that only works for tests that run within a
single JVM and I've not got it working with code that does bytecode
fiddling of its own.

--Nat
